title: Safety and Efficacy of ORM-12741 on Cognitive and Behavioral Symptoms in Patients With Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: The purpose of this study is to determine whether ORM-12741 is safe and effective in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.
description_detailed: The purpose of this study is to determine whether ORM-12741 is safe and effective in the treatment of cognitive and behavioral symptoms in patients with Alzheimer's disease.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: A total of 132 subjects were screened and 100 were randomized to 3 treatment groups. 30 patients were excluded prior randomization due to inclusion/exclusion criteria, 2 due to personal reasons.
participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: This study was conducted in 4 countries (18 centres): Finland, Poland, Romania and Spain. Of these, 1 centre screened but did not randomise any subjects. Study period was 27 Apr 2011-21 Sep 2012 (first subject first visit to last subject last visit).

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: Placebo for ORM-12741: Placebo twice a day

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Participants With Adverse Events
outcomeMeasures.description: Adverse events from start of ORM-12741 treatment until end of study visit.

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: Placebo for ORM-12741: Placebo twice a day

outcomeMeasures.title: Quality of Episodic Memory
outcomeMeasures.description: The Cognitive Drug Research (CDR) computerised battery tests is designed to evaluate the effects of novel compounds on the quality of cognitive functioning. Quality of Episodic Memory measures the capability of maintaining information in episodic memory and is assessed as the sum of sensitivity indices from 4 memory tasks on the CDR computerised battery tests. Values are calculated by a computer and higher scores mean better outcome.

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: Placebo for ORM-12741: Placebo twice a day

outcomeMeasures.title: Quality of Working Memory
outcomeMeasures.description: The Cognitive Drug Research (CDR) computerised battery tests is designed to evaluate the effects of novel compounds on the quality of cognitive functioning. Quality of Working Memory measures the capability of maintaining information in working memory and is assessed as the sum of sensitivity indices from 2 memory tasks on the CDR computerised battery tests. Values are calculated by a computer and higher scores mean better outcome.

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: Placebo for ORM-12741: Placebo twice a day

outcomeMeasures.title: Quality of Memory
outcomeMeasures.description: The Cognitive Drug Research (CDR) computerised battery tests is designed to evaluate the effects of novel compounds on the quality of cognitive functioning. Quality of Memory is a combination of outcome measures Quality of Working Memory \& Quality of Episodic Memory. Values are calculated by a computer and higher scores mean better outcome.

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: Placebo for ORM-12741: Placebo twice a day

outcomeMeasures.title: Speed of Memory
outcomeMeasures.description: The Cognitive Drug Research (CDR) computerised battery tests is designed to evaluate the effects of novel compounds on the quality of cognitive functioning. Speed of Memory is assessed as the sum of speed measures from 2 memory tasks and 2 recognition tasks on the CDR computerised battery tests. Values are calculated by a computer and higher scores mean better outcome.

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: Placebo for ORM-12741: Placebo twice a day

outcomeMeasures.title: Power of Attention
outcomeMeasures.description: The Cognitive Drug Research (CDR) computerised battery tests is designed to evaluate the effects of novel compounds on the quality of cognitive functioning. Power of attention measures speed and attention and is assessed from 3 attentional tasks on the CDR computerised battery tests. Values are calculated by a computer and higher scores mean better outcome.

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: Placebo for ORM-12741: Placebo twice a day

outcomeMeasures.title: Continuity of Attention
outcomeMeasures.description: The Cognitive Drug Research (CDR) computerised battery tests is designed to evaluate the effects of novel compounds on the quality of cognitive functioning. Continuity of attention measures speed and accuracy and is calculated from 3 attentional tasks on the CDR computerised battery tests. Values are calculated by a computer and higher scores mean better outcome.

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: Placebo for ORM-12741: Placebo twice a day

outcomeMeasures.title: NPI Total Score
outcomeMeasures.description: The total score of Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI) was assessed by a caregiver interview. 10 behavioral areas were included: Delusions, Hallucinations, Agitation/Aggression, Depression/Dysphoria, Anxiety, Elation/Euphoria, Apathy/Indifference, Disinhibition, Irritability/Lability, and Aberrant Motor Behaviour. Higher scores mean worse outcome. Minimum value 0, maximum value 120.

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: Placebo for ORM-12741: Placebo twice a day

outcomeMeasures.title: Caregiver Distress Score
outcomeMeasures.description: Caregiver distress score generated by adding together the scores of individual NPI distress questions of Neuropsychiatric Inventory NPI. Higher scores mean worse outcome. Minimum value 0, maximum value 120.

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: Placebo for ORM-12741: Placebo twice a day

outcomeMeasures.title: Pharmacokinetics of ORM-12741
outcomeMeasures.description: ORM-12741 plasma trough concentrations at week 12.

explanation_target: Reason: The trial title and purpose state the drug is tested for cognitive and behavioral symptoms in Alzheimer's disease; ORM-12741 is described in the literature as a selective antagonist of the alpha‑2C adrenergic receptor (a small‑molecule neuromodulator), i.e., a symptomatic (neuromodulatory) approach rather than an anti‑amyloid or anti‑tau disease‑modifying therapy. citeturn0search2turn0search3

Act: Key extracted details and web search results — ORM‑12741 is a synthetic small‑molecule developed by Orion (later DB105 in some sources) and acts as a selective α2C‑adrenoceptor antagonist; it was tested in a randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled Phase 2a AD trial that assessed cognitive outcomes (Cognitive Drug Research system) and neuropsychiatric outcomes (Neuropsychiatric Inventory). The Phase 2a report showed a positive effect on an episodic memory endpoint and on caregiver distress (NPI), and separate PET/receptor‑occupancy work confirms brain penetration and α2C receptor engagement. citeturn0search2turn0search3turn0search1

Reflect: Classification justification and caveats — ORM‑12741 is not a biologic and does not target canonical AD pathology (amyloid/tau), so it does not fit 'disease‑targeted biologic' or 'disease‑targeted small molecule' (those categories imply targeting Alzheimer pathology). Because its mechanism is neuromodulatory to improve cognition/symptoms, the closest category is 'Cognitive enhancer'. Note: the trial explicitly targeted both cognitive and behavioral (neuropsychiatric) symptoms — therefore there is overlap with 'Neuropsychiatric symptom improvement'; the primary cognitive endpoints and the trial title justify choosing 'Cognitive enhancer' while acknowledging the dual symptomatic aim. Supporting sources: Phase‑2 trial report (PMC/PubMed), PET occupancy/translational study, and drug monograph entries. citeturn0search2turn0search3turn0search1
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational drug ORM-12741 is a small‑molecule selective antagonist of the α2C‑adrenoceptor (an adrenergic neurotransmitter G‑protein coupled receptor). The trial tested it as a symptomatic/cognitive‑enhancing agent for cognitive and behavioral symptoms in AD rather than as an anti‑amyloid or anti‑tau disease‑modifying therapy. citeturn0search1turn0search4

Act: Extracted facts and assignment — ORM‑12741 has high affinity and selectivity for the human α2C‑adrenoceptor, shows brain penetration and receptor occupancy in human PET studies, and produced signals on episodic memory and neuropsychiatric endpoints in a Phase 2a trial. These properties identify the molecular target as a neurotransmitter receptor (adrenergic α2C), so the most specific CADRO category is D) Neurotransmitter Receptors. citeturn0search1turn0search4turn0search3

Reflect: The classification aligns with the mechanism: blocking an adrenergic receptor is a neuromodulatory approach (symptomatic/cognitive enhancement) and does not target core AD pathologies (amyloid, tau, etc.). No evidence in the cited material indicates multi‑target disease modification, so D) is appropriate. Key supporting sources are a translational PET occupancy study and the Phase 2a clinical trial report. citeturn0search1turn0search4
- Translational PET/receptor‑occupancy study showing ORM‑12741 is a selective α2C‑AR antagonist with human brain occupancy. citeturn0search1
- Phase 2a randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled AD trial reporting cognitive (episodic memory) and neuropsychiatric effects and safety data. citeturn0search4
- Orion press release / company description summarizing the Phase II data and mechanism (α2C antagonist). citeturn0search3
